Witnesse, the first hand which was subscribed to one Coppy of your Petition, which was a Ministers, who is noted for a desperate Malignant. And Sr. Ch. A. the onely Knight I know you can bragge of; and this well-affected man was sequestred, and newly come home from Newarke; 'tis possible something might be promised him from these men too; or at least hee might bee
feared by them. Delinquents, Malignants, Drunkards, Swearers, all well-affected? others seduced deceived At last with this scraping, and omnium gatherum, they come to the Court of Major and Aldermen; they with a great deale of Indignation, and Odium, threw it out. Then they brought it to the Committee for the County. In the Interim, some discreet and well-affected Gentlemen, having notice of these under-board practices, drew another Petition, which owned the Covenant and Presbyteriall government modestly. To which Petition, the Major, and well affected Aldermen, subscribed. A Coppy whereof, was sent to the Gentlemen of the County, and well-affected people, (not to Delinquents, Sir, nor Newarkers.) The subscription was deferred, by some of the Knights, and Gentlemens appoyntment, till there were a generall meeting of the whole Committee of the County, which was to be about a fortnight after. In the meane time, they had the Petition returned, with some things altered and some thing added; with a desire that it might be prepared against the meeting. Two, or three were appointed for that purpose: but upon second thoughts (hints being given out by the Independents, that if this Petition might be laid down, they would lay downe theirs) and regarding the Juncture of time, being when the house was sending away the Propositions, it was concluded, to proceed no further for the present, in that, or any other, Petition. But we thought, lesse could not stand with good manners, then at the day when the Committee met, who had pleased, in the generall, to owne our Petition; then to go up, and, tendring our service, thanke them; and declare our latter resolutions; and, as we thought (for the present) more expedient thoughts: Cōming thither, (beyond expectation) they met with Mr. H. K & Mr. G. B. in an out-room, where, after some conference about both the Petition, a motion was made, that the controversie should be referred to the Committe then met, if they would be pleased to trouble themselves with it. Who, though their occasions were great at present, gave the gentlemen audience: and after some debate, the major part advised us, that both Petitions should be laid aside for the present, in respect of the weighty affaires the Parl. had then in debate. The Ministers, and well affected, presently condescended; but Mr. H. K & Mr. G. B being desired to do the same, answered, (according to Lilbourns president) They were free born subjects, Whereupon the Committee shewed great dislike of their carriage. And the Ministers finding such candid, and courteous, carriage from the gentlemen of the Committee, did engage themselves, not to set any Petition on foot, before they had first acquainted the said Cōmittee with it, and imparted it to them, (provided, that the other party of Independents, Malignants, &c. should do the same. Their answer was still, They were free borne Subjects. But the Ministers engaged themselves, that they would stand to what they had promised. And at their parting Mr. Thornbeck made this motion to the Board: That in case these Sectaries should (all this notwithstanding) proceed in theirs, the Committee would be pleased to discountenance and suppresse them: Which then one of them promised he would doe; and so he thought the rest would. None gain-sayed it. The Committee thanked the Ministers for their honest and plaine dealing; and as much checked the other: The Ministers taking their leave, Mr. Carter made this motion; That that Worshipfull Board, would be pleased to take especiall notice (as no question they did) of eithers carryage and iudge accordingly.

Thus (Reader) thou hast the perfect story Now (brother) who was the Jugler? who the Jesuite? who the State-disturbers? who the pertinacious conceited men? Is this true now, thinke you, that you are meer passive creatures, and act nothing? that dare send out Petitions in the name of the Committee, without their knowledg, and controul the whole Committee? Are you the onely free born subiects of the kingdom? Is it your Birth-right to petition, & not ours? Is it a state-disturbance for us to petition, & not for you too? remember what you writ p. 2. Is it none for you, though the whole Committee for the county be against you? Alas, you are holy, harmles, peaceable (speak truth Sir) creatures, useful to the publike: for what? to set it on fire? But I must take notice of the Petition, p. 16. being you have printed Either our counsell,
or yours told us it was a breach of priviledge of Parliament, & high forfeiture, to print any thing that was directed to the Parliament, whether Petition or Remonstrance, &c before i • had been presented to the House.

But these are the priviledged men, that can break no priviledges, forfeit no estate: but why do you say, The Humble Petition of the Knights, &c. What Knight? Sir, except Sir Christopher Atto, just let out of Newarke. Ge tlemen? which of them, Sir; did not the whole board declare against you? Free-holders; how many of them Sir? and Inhabitants of the Cou • ty of Norfolke What Inhabitants? Men, women, the boyes, girles, simple people that knew nothing, but were Tenants, or in some relation to you? And the City of Norwich. What more still? why then did the Ma • or and Aldermen, and that representative Citie cast it out? it should have run thus. The Petition of the Independents, Delinquents, Malignants, Anabaptists, Antinomia • s, Gallioes, and 2 or 3 honester men of the County of Norfolke, and County and City of Norwich. For the Petition it selfe, let the Parliament judg it. They have appealed thither, thither let them goe. Here was the Rise, Progresse, and Ruine of it.

Nor was this their first jugling with petitioning. Once before they sent out a dangerous Petition, which (if I mistake not) was, for an intolerable Toleration. This was likewise sent out from the same hands in the name of the Committeee for the County of Norfolke: the manner was to have Copies of it drawn, and (as I am informed) when any of the Country-men came about any County-bus ness, he was by one or two of them calld aside, and a copy given to them to get hands to, as a Petition from the Committee. This was likewise discovered by a discreet Gentleman at W • ndham, and taken from Captaine B and this Gentleman brought it to one of the Committee, who the next day carried it to the Committee: who all disclaimed it, except those two which were the Authors of it, and resented the matter of so high concernment, and so scandalous, that some of the Gentlemen present thought it fit they should be censured for that abuse of the Country-Gentlemen, and lesse-understanding people. But in conclusion they were well • hidden for it, and the matter buried.

Reader, Ex ungue leonem. Construe these men as you find them, and trust them according to their trustinesse. I had thought to have added here a full relation of their rise, progresse, number, and carriage in this Citie. And to have answered the latter part of the Booke falsly stiled Vox Populi. But, it would for the present take up too much time, and I am willing to pursue the Fox while the sent is hot. I am confident some of the Ministers too will take them to task, and an answer for themselves. But if not, I shall in convenient time delineate them, and give thee a perfect draught, and stop the mouth of Vox Populi, and present thee with their cry against that Faction, and their undermining dealings amongst us. But let mee acquaint thee what entertainment this scurrilous pamphlet found in this Citie. Threescore and odde of them were sent down to Mr. I. T. (they say) a chiefe Independent in this City: which being discovered to the Right Worshipfull the Major of the Citie: hee viewing the Book, altogether a libellous scandall, belying both the Magistracy and the Ministerie, and reviling all, and having no Imprimatur to it; sends one of his Officers and ceaseth upon the packet as unlicensed libellous printed untruths: for hee durst nor credit that piece of the Frontispiece Licensed and entred according to Order except he knew by whom) and tooke them to his Custody till he should find out who licensed them, who writ them, & who published them, that the Author might be proceeded against as a Libeller, & if the book bee not licensed (as no rationall man can beleeve) we wil tell you the end of it hereafter. Till when, goood Reader farewell.

For the latter part Vox Populi, it is wholly true for the matter. If one word were but added to the Title, & it were Vox Populi Independentis: Who say Their tongues are their own & they will speake, and must do so too, till God & Authority stop their mouths. Quod faxit Deus.
